conclusion: Understanding the velocity-time graph with velocity on the y-axis and time on the x-axis.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.
Understanding 'variable linear motion' as motion with changing velocity.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s: velocity is constant at 2 m/s, indicating uniform linear motion.
From t = 1 to t = 2 s: velocity is decreasing linearly, indicating variable linear motion.
From t = 2 to t = 3 s: velocity is decreasing linearly, indicating variable linear motion.
In the first 3 seconds, the particle has periods of both uniform and variable linear motion.
Overall in the first 3 seconds, there is variable linear motion due to changing velocity.
Considering the entire 3-second interval, the velocity changes from 2 m/s to -2 m/s.
Reaffirming the definition of variable linear motion as involving a change in velocity.
The particle starts with a constant velocity, decelerates to zero, then accelerates negatively.
Conclusion: The particle did undergo variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds.
